article.title: Multiplicity fluctuations in Ar+Sc collisions at the CERN SPS from NA61/SHINE

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the effect of correction procedures on the scaled variance (w[N]) of charged hadrons. What is the main conclusion we can draw from this figure?
choices: The corrections have a negligible effect on the overall trend of w[N].
The corrections significantly increase the value of w[N] at all energies.
The corrections shift the peak of w[N] to a higher energy.
The corrections are only relevant for the EPOS 1.99 simulation, not the actual data.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 illustrates the energy dependence of w[N] for different hadron types. What trend is observed for the most central Ar+Sc collisions?
choices: A strong peak in w[N] at low energies, followed by a decrease at higher energies.
A relatively flat energy dependence with a small enhancement around 8A GeV/c.
A continuous increase in w[N] with increasing energy for all hadron types.
A significant difference in the energy dependence of w[N] between different hadron types.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 compares the energy dependence of  立[N, Ep] and w[N] for central Ar+Sc collisions with w[N] for p+p data. What significant difference is observed?
choices: 立[N, Ep] shows a clear peak at low energies, while w[N] does not for both collision systems.
w[N] for p+p data is significantly higher than both 立[N, Ep] and w[N] for Ar+Sc collisions across all energies.
立[N, Ep] and w[N] for Ar+Sc collisions overlap almost perfectly, indicating no significant difference between them.
w[N] for Ar+Sc collisions is consistently higher than w[N] for p+p data, especially at high energies.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 presents the scaled variance for negatively charged hadrons in different collision systems, comparing experimental data with theoretical predictions. What is the main conclusion based on this comparison?
choices: The Wounded Nucleon Model accurately predicts the experimental data for all collision systems.
The experimental data for central Pb+Pb and Ar+Sc collisions at high energies contradict the Wounded Nucleon Model.
The Poisson model provides a good description of the p+p data but fails to describe the heavy-ion collision data.
There is no significant difference in the scaled variance between p+p and heavy-ion collisions.
